description: From Middle English swathe, swath, from Old English swaþu, swæþ (“bandage”), probably akin to Old English swaþul, sweþel (“a swathe, wrap, band, bandage”).
From Middle English swathen, from Old English *swaþian, akin to Old English besweþian (“to swathe, swaddle”).

verbs.description: swathe (third-person singular simple present swathes, present participle swathing, simple past and past participle swathed)

entries.meaning: To bind with a swathe, band, bandage, or rollers
examples: Their children are never swathed, or bound about with any thing when they are first born' but are put naked into the bed with their parents to lie.

description: From Middle English swathe, from Old English swaþu (“track, trace”), from Proto-Germanic *swaþō. More at swath.

examples: As well as the advantages of abused office, Mr Chávez can boast enduring popularity among a broad swathe of poorer Venezuelans. They like him for his charisma, humble background and demotic speech.
